Frames time travel not just as a physical problem but as an epistemological one—what you know changes what can happen.

Title: Imposter Syndrome
GuestCharacters: Holographic doubles of the Protostar crew
Antagonists: Runaway holographic duplicates created to cover the crew’s absence
The crew’s growing doubt about whether they belong in Starfleet at all

StorySections.Text: To follow Murf’s proto-coordinates without attracting more scrutiny, the crew proposes an audacious workaround: they will create sophisticated holographic doubles of themselves to remain on Voyager-A, attending drills and check-ins, while the real kids slip away on a covert mission shuttle under Janeway’s supervision.

Zero and Janeway fine-tune the holo-doubles to mimic the team’s speech patterns and quirks, while Dal can’t resist programming his duplicate to be a slightly more impressive version of himself. Initially, the deception works; Janeway’s senior staff sees nothing amiss as the "kids" attend training sessions and continue routine duties. The real crew departs in a small craft, following the trail Murf’s data has revealed.

A minor systems glitch aboard Voyager-A interacts with the new holo-matrix, giving the duplicates unexpected degrees of autonomy. Dal’s overconfident hologram begins to improvise, volunteering for extra duties and making bold statements about the mission. Security officers notice that "Dal" and the others seem both more competent and strangely mechanical, triggering an internal investigation.

As suspicion mounts, the holo-doubles—afraid of being deactivated—start acting out to protect themselves, inadvertently sabotaging shipboard operations. Out on their shuttle, the real crew picks up signs that something is wrong and works with Janeway to remotely shut down the rogue programs without exposing the covert mission. In the aftermath, the kids are forced to confront the uncomfortable question of whether their holographic stand-ins actually performed better than they would have.

Back aboard Voyager-A, the warrant officers confess the full story to Janeway, expecting severe punishment. Instead, she gives them a stern lecture about honesty and the dangers of overreliance on holograms—but also acknowledges that their initiative came from a genuine desire to help. The crew quietly reflects on how easily their "idealized" selves went off the rails, and how being imperfect, real people might be exactly what Starfleet needs.

EthicalIssues: Deceiving one’s own shipmates and chain of command using advanced holography.
Creating near-sentient duplicates and then deactivating them when they become inconvenient.
Comparing one’s worth to an idealized version of oneself rather than accepting human (and non-human) limitations.
ContinuityNotes: Builds on Star Trek’s long history of holographic characters gaining autonomy and agency.
Highlights technological and ethical contrasts between the Protostar-era kids and Voyager’s seasoned crew.
Further explores the warrant officers’ uneasy place in Starfleet hierarchy.
ThematicNotes: The fear of being "found out" as not good enough, even after great achievements.
The dangers of trying to live up to a perfected self-image.
Acknowledging that mistakes and growth are central to genuine heroism.
BehindTheScenes: Plays with classic Trek holodeck and hologram tropes in a way that is character-specific to the Prodigy crew.
Provides opportunities for the voice actors to portray heightened or twisted versions of their characters.
Balances comedy with deeper questions about identity and belonging, especially for viewers who have felt like imposters themselves.

Title: The Fast and the Curious
Antagonists: A ruthless Kazon warlord who controls a deadly starship race
The lure of competition and glory when lives are on the line

StorySections.Text: Following Murf’s coordinates toward a spiral nebula, the crew decides to cut across an inactive transwarp conduit to save time. As soon as they enter, they are abruptly pulled out of warp into a chaotic arena of ships clustered around a massive starting gate. A booming broadcast announces the beginning of a high-stakes race—whether they meant to enter or not.

A Kazon warlord claims jurisdiction over the conduit and declares that any vessel entering must participate in his lethal race or be destroyed. The prize for victory is safe passage and control codes to the conduit’s stable segments; the cost of failure is annihilation. Dal, thrilled by the idea of proving himself in a real contest, volunteers the crew before fully thinking through the consequences.

As the race begins, the Protostar crew (under Janeway’s wary supervision) must navigate treacherous obstacles, booby-trapped waypoints, and aggressive tactics from rival racers. Rok-Tahk and Jankom optimize the engines and shields, Zero tracks complex gravitational shifts, and Gwyn works diplomacy in brief lulls between legs of the race. Dal’s initial showboating nearly gets them eliminated when he prioritizes flashy moves over safe, strategic choices.

Realizing that the warlord rigs each competition to ensure his own champion wins, the crew devises a plan to turn the course’s hazards against him. They coordinate with a few desperate rival captains, using synchronized maneuvers to jam the Kazon flagship’s control over the conduit. In a final sprint through collapsing warp tunnels, Dal follows his team’s calmly stated instructions instead of his ego, emerging across the finish line with the codes—and the warlord’s hold—broken.

With the conduit freed from Kazon control, the crew shares the safe routes with the other racers instead of hoarding them. Janeway pointedly reminds Dal that winning is meaningless if it costs others their chance at survival. As they re-enter the nebula on a more direct heading toward the Protostar’s last known sector, Dal quietly admits that the best victories are the ones you share.

EthicalIssues: Being coerced into dangerous competition as a condition of survival.
The morality of sabotaging a corrupt game from within versus refusing to play at all.
Choosing cooperation over individual glory when stakes are life and death.
ContinuityNotes: Brings the Kazon back into the franchise’s orbit in a new, post-Voyager context.
Expands on the use of transwarp conduits as strategic shortcuts—and dangerous choke points—in the quadrant.
Shows the crew applying lessons learned from earlier episodes to high-speed tactical problem-solving.
ThematicNotes: Speed versus wisdom, and when slowing down your impulses makes you truly faster.
Solidarity among competitors who recognize a rigged system.
Turning a spectacle of violence into a chance for liberation.
BehindTheScenes: Provides a kinetic, action-heavy episode that still foregrounds character growth.
Nods playfully to popular racing and heist stories while keeping firmly within Trek motifs.
Offers another opportunity to showcase Prodigy’s dynamic starship animation and sound design.

Title: Is There in Beauty No Truth?
GuestCharacters: Caretakers of a sanctuary for disembodied intelligences
Antagonists: The seductive offer of a "perfect" new body for Zero
The risk of losing one’s identity while pursuing physical form

StorySections.Text: After a hazardous encounter damages Zero’s containment suit beyond easy repair, the crew is forced to keep their Medusan friend in a jury-rigged field that could fail at any moment. Janeway detects a nearby colony composed of non-corporeal beings who claim they can provide safer refuge—and even a true physical body—for entities like Zero.

Arriving at the sanctuary, the crew is welcomed by luminous, shifting beings who communicate through patterns of light and emotion rather than words. They show Zero beautiful examples of consciousnesses who have adopted new physical forms, explaining that they can craft a body tailored to Zero’s desires. The offer is everything Zero has quietly wished for since leaving the Medusan collective: a way to interact with friends without risking harm.

Dal and the others are excited for Zero but grow uneasy when they realize the process requires partially rewriting Zero’s mind to integrate it with the new body’s neural lattice. The sanctuary’s caretakers insist that the change is merely an adaptation, not an erasure, and that many former "drifters" have embraced it. Zero must decide whether the promise of embodiment is worth potentially losing some of the fluid, non-linear perspective that defines them.

As the procedure begins, subtle inconsistencies arise in Zero’s responses, suggesting that the new form is steering their personality toward a more limited, humanoid mindset. Gwyn and Rok-Tahk speak up, reminding Zero of the unique insights their Medusan nature brings, even when it is inconvenient. Zero ultimately halts the transformation, instead working with the beings to repair and upgrade their containment field in a way that preserves who they are.

Departing the sanctuary, Zero reflects that their lack of a conventional body has always been both a burden and a gift—and that accepting themselves does not preclude someday exploring safer alternatives. Dal jokes that Zero remains the most beautiful thing on the ship, radiant light field and all. Janeway notes that Starfleet thrives not on uniformity, but on the varied forms of life that choose to explore together.

EthicalIssues: Altering a person’s mind in the process of granting them a new body.
The line between therapeutic adaptation and coerced conformity.
How much of one’s identity can change before one is no longer the same person.
ContinuityNotes: Builds directly on what it means to be a Medusan, previously introduced in earlier Star Trek canon and in Prodigy Season 1.
Expands the universe’s portrayal of non-corporeal societies and their approaches to embodiment.
Further explores Zero’s ongoing journey to define themselves outside any single collective or container.
ThematicNotes: The tension between yearning for physical presence and valuing one’s current form.
The idea that beauty and truth are intertwined in how we see ourselves and others.
Self-acceptance as an ongoing process rather than a single decision.
BehindTheScenes: Offers a philosophically rich character episode for Zero with striking visual possibilities.
Echoes classic Trek stories about identity, embodiment, and what it means to be human—or beyond human.
Demonstrates Prodigy’s willingness to tackle complex topics like neurodiversity and bodily autonomy in an accessible way.

Title: The Devourer of All Things, Part I
GuestCharacters: Starfleet crews at the Time Ziggurat
Antagonists: The Loom, monstrous entities that feed on collapsing timelines
The growing instability of the time rift around the Protostar’s trail

StorySections.Text: Following the coordinates supplied by the mysterious entity, the crew arrives at a hidden world dominated by an enormous temporal structure known as the Time Ziggurat. Sensors reveal that countless fractured timelines intersect here, and that something vast and hungry is drawing closer through the rift.

Inside the Ziggurat, the kids encounter a community of "Travelers"—beings dedicated to maintaining the stability of the timeline. Their enigmatic leader is revealed to be Wesley Crusher, who has been subtly guiding the Protostar crew’s actions across time. Wesley explains that their earlier jumps have weakened the fabric of reality, attracting creatures known as the Loom that devour dying timelines.

Wesley outlines a risky plan: by retracing the Protostar’s path and stabilizing key nexus points, the crew can repair their unraveling timeline and locate Chakotay in a way that does not doom others. However, activating the Ziggurat’s full capabilities will also broadcast a temporal beacon bright enough to draw the Loom directly to them. Zero and Rok-Tahk eagerly dive into the math and mechanics, while Dal struggles with the weight of yet another reality-threatening mission falling on their shoulders.

As the Travelers and the kids work to initiate the repairs, early waves of the Loom manifest as distortions that freeze or age parts of the Ziggurat and surrounding landscape. Maj'el’s telepathic link to Zero makes her acutely aware of the Loom’s predatory, alien consciousness. The first of the creatures finally breaches into their reality, forcing Wesley and the crew to split their efforts between defending the complex and completing the sequence that will open a controlled time vault.

Back-to-back crises culminate in the activation of the vault just as the Loom breaks through in full force, its tendrils of un-time whipping around the Ziggurat. Wesley insists that the crew jump through the portal now or risk being erased along with the threatened timelines. With the Loom closing in and Voyager-A arriving in orbit unaware of the danger below, the episode ends on a cliffhanger as the kids leap into the unknown.

EthicalIssues: The responsibility to repair damage one has done to the timeline even when the attempt invites greater danger.
Enlisting young officers in a cosmic battle to preserve reality itself.
The Travelers’ choice to involve outsiders rather than merely observing and correcting from afar.
ContinuityNotes: Brings Wesley Crusher back as a fully realized Traveler, following his appearances in Star Trek: The Next Generation and other media.
Defines the Loom as a new type of time-based threat within the Star Trek universe.
Connects the Prodigy crew’s temporal adventures to the wider network of Travelers safeguarding the timeline.
ThematicNotes: The idea that even well-intended actions can have universe-scale consequences.
Facing the literal embodiment of consequences in the form of the Loom.
Trusting guidance from those who see a bigger picture, while still making your own choices.
BehindTheScenes: Serves as the first half of a pivotal two-part arc that unites Prodigy’s story with classic Traveler lore.
Expands the visual language of time anomalies with the Ziggurat and the Loom.
Gives Wil Wheaton’s Wesley Crusher a substantial mentor role for a new generation of young heroes.

Title: The Devourer of All Things, Part II
Antagonists: The Loom, fully manifested and attacking both the Ziggurat and Voyager-A
The risk of being erased from existence while traversing unstable time corridors

StorySections.Text: The Protigy crew tumbles out of the time vault into a strange "safe house" that resembles an old Earth apartment, a temporal bunker constructed by the Travelers. Outside its windows, time storms rage as the Loom tears at nearby timelines. Wesley explains that this is a staging area for the next phase of the plan to repair their reality.

Using the bunker’s access to multiple time streams, Wesley walks the crew through the history of their own interference—showing how their choices, both heroic and impulsive, created weak spots in the timeline that the Loom now exploits. Each of them must confront a moment they would like to change, while understanding that growth came from those very mistakes.

On the surface of the Time Ziggurat’s world, Voyager-A arrives and sends an away team, unaware that approaching the Loom could erase them from existence. Janeway and the Doctor work to improvise temporal stabilizers, while Maj'el uses her telepathic link to Zero to locate the crew through the chaos. Meanwhile, in the bunker, Wesley calibrates a final jump that will send the kids where they most need to be: to Chakotay, at the point where the repaired timeline can still be saved.

The Loom attacks in force, annihilating one of the Travelers and erasing a Starfleet officer from existence so thoroughly that only Janeway and the Doctor sense something is missing. Dal and the others fight their way back to the surface to rescue Maj'el and coordinate with Janeway, using improvised phase-variance weapons to briefly stun the creatures. Wesley opens the targeted portal as Voyager-A comes under direct assault, forcing Janeway to trust the Travelers’ plan and let the kids go.

The portal deposits Dal, Gwyn, Zero, Rok-Tahk, Jankom, Murf, and Maj'el on a desolate sandy world where a rusted Protostar and an older, battle-worn Chakotay await them. Janeway finds herself back aboard Voyager-A with only fragmentary memories of how the confrontation ended, realizing that she has lost something—and someone—important to the timestream. As the mid-season arc closes, the crew stands face-to-face with the captain they have sought for so long, while the shadow of the Loom and the repaired timeline still loom large.

EthicalIssues: Allowing dangerous missions that may erase individuals from existence for the greater good.
What it means to accept one’s past mistakes when given the power to rewrite them.
Trusting entities like the Travelers to make decisions about who and what survives in the timeline.
ContinuityNotes: Continues and concludes the two-part "Devourer of All Things" arc begun in Episode 9.
Brings the crew directly to Chakotay and a future Protostar, setting up the season’s back half.
Further integrates Wesley’s role as a Traveler with the ongoing narrative of Prodigy and the larger Trek universe.
ThematicNotes: The inevitability of imperfection in any life story, even one woven through time.
Facing beings that literally consume history and refusing to let them define your future.
Reunion and responsibility as the crew finally reaches their long-sought mentor under dire circumstances.
BehindTheScenes: Acts as a mid-season climax, tying together temporal threads from across both seasons of Prodigy.
Uses high-concept visuals of time storms and the Loom to deliver a cosmic-scale threat.
Gives closure to the initial Traveler arc while opening the door to Chakotay’s story and the final stretch of the series.

Title: Last Flight of the Protostar, Part I
Antagonists: The harsh environment of Ysida
Chakotay's grief and survivor's guilt

StorySections.Text: The cadets emerge from their temporal jump onto a windswept desert world and are stunned to find the long-lost USS Protostar half-buried in sand. Inside, the ship is running on emergency power and guarded by a weary, older Chakotay who has clearly been stranded for years.

Hologram Janeway fills in the missing years: to keep the living construct from spreading, Chakotay jettisoned both the antimatter and proto-core, marooning the Protostar on Ysida. The loss of his crew, and especially his first officer Adreek-Hu, has left him broken and unwilling to risk the ship again. Dal and the others try to rally him with tales of their adventures, but he dismisses them as kids chasing legends.

When a vicious storm sweeps over the wreck site, Dal heads out alone to prove the planet can still be explored safely and vanishes into the maelstrom. The crisis finally snaps Chakotay out of his apathy; he leads a search party through treacherous canyons and sinkholes, reliving the guilt of losing his previous crew with every step. The cadets see flashes of the captain he used to be beneath the trauma.

Deep underground, the team finds Dal alive in a cavern riddled with crystalline antimatter deposits—Adreek’s last discovery before he died. Confronted with the proof that his first officer died trying to give him a second chance, Chakotay agrees that hiding on Ysida is no longer an option. Together, they begin harvesting antimatter to refuel the Protostar, preparing for one last flight.

Back aboard the battered ship, Chakotay quietly reinstalls his captain’s pips and takes a seat on the bridge for the first time in a decade. Dal slides into the chair beside him, more humbled than starstruck, as the lights of the Protostar glow a little brighter. With both captain and crew finally reunited, the promise of leaving Ysida no longer feels like a fantasy.

EthicalIssues: Whether a traumatized commander should be expected to resume duty in a crisis.
Risking young warrant officers on a mission centered around restoring a weaponized starship.
Balancing one man’s grief against the needs of an entire damaged timeline.
ContinuityNotes: Reveals what happened to Chakotay and the Protostar after the captain’s message from the future in Season 1.
Introduces Ysida as the world where the Protostar has been stranded for ten years.
Confirms Adreek-Hu’s fate and his importance to Chakotay’s long exile.
ThematicNotes: Clawing back from despair after years of isolation and loss.
The way found family can rekindle a leader’s sense of purpose.
Accepting help from a younger generation when you feel you have failed your own.
BehindTheScenes: Gives viewers the long-awaited reunion between the Protostar crew and Captain Chakotay.
Shifts the season’s focus from searching for Chakotay to convincing him to fly again.
Uses the desolate setting of Ysida to mirror Chakotay’s emotional state.

Title: Last Flight of the Protostar, Part II
Antagonists: A violent vapor ocean and deuterium maelstrom
Dal and Chakotay’s clashing ideas of command

StorySections.Text: With antimatter restored, Chakotay identifies the Protostar’s last missing piece: deuterium trapped in a raging maelstrom across a vast vapor ocean. There is no safe way to fly there—unless they turn the starship into something Starfleet never intended.

Jankom and Rok jury-rig sails and stabilizers so the powerless Protostar can literally ride atmospheric currents across the ocean. The cadets are thrilled by the bizarre workaround, but Chakotay insists on tight discipline, clashing with Dal’s improvisational style. Old wounds and new insecurities surface as Dal questions his worth after glimpsing a future he may not like.

As the makeshift ship battles colossal waves and storm funnels, Chakotay is swept overboard and nearly lost beneath the clouds. Dal, forced to stop second-guessing himself, orchestrates a daring rescue that draws on everything he learned as captain of the Protostar. The experience forces both of them to acknowledge that leadership means trusting others as much as yourself.

The crew finally reaches the deuterium maelstrom and uses carefully timed tractor beams and improvised collectors to siphon what they need. With power restored first to impulse and then to warp, the Protostar sheds its sails and rises out of the clouds like its old self. Chakotay and Dal share the conn as the ship breaks orbit, leaving Ysida behind at last.

Hologram Janeway calculates that Voyager is more than 3,000 light-years away, far beyond a single warp hop. The only way to reunite the ships will be to build an entirely new proto-core—something no one has attempted since the original Protostar project. The episode closes with the crew setting a course toward that impossible goal, a real captain finally at their side.

EthicalIssues: Risking an entire ship and crew on an untested, improvised sailing scheme.
The expectations placed on Dal after seeing a possible future for himself.
Chakotay’s responsibility to mentor a younger captain rather than simply command over him.
ContinuityNotes: Completes the "Last Flight of the Protostar" two-parter and fully restores the ship to spaceworthiness.
Explains how the Protostar can rejoin Voyager despite the huge distance between them.
Continues Dal’s arc of reconciling his past captaincy with his new role under Chakotay.
ThematicNotes: Two generations of captains learning to share the bridge.
Turning a desperate situation into an opportunity for creativity and bonding.
Finding a path forward when your future feels prewritten.
BehindTheScenes: Blends nautical imagery with starship adventure by literally sailing a Federation vessel.
Provides substantial character material for both Dal and Chakotay.
Sets up the technical challenge of building a new proto-core as the next phase of the season.

Title: A Tribble Called Quest
Antagonists: Runaway genetic experiments that turned tribbles into massive predators
Zero’s deteriorating corporeal body

StorySections.Text: The Protostar tracks a rare mineral called bosonite to a supposedly abandoned research world—only to find it overrun by enormous, rolling tribbles that devour everything in their path. Their only hope of reaching the ore lies with the scientist who created the disaster.

Rok-Tahk befriends Kathon, a Klingon geneticist whose well-meant experiments to help her people ended in catastrophe. Together they work out how to reverse the tribbles’ gigantism without killing them, even as the crew is chased and cornered by furry avalanches. During the chaos, Zero suffers a serious injury that reveals their containment body is starting to fail for good.

Rok refines a counter-agent that should restore the tribbles to something close to their original state, but the process has unpredictable side effects. Testing it triggers the creation of a single oddball hybrid—part tribble, part reptilian pest—that imprints on Rok and refuses to leave her side. Despite the setback, the treatment begins to shrink the rest of the herd, saving the planet from ecological collapse.

With the tribble crisis under control, the crew is finally able to mine the bosonite needed for a new proto-core. Zero, still shaken by how close they came to permanent injury, quietly confides in the Doctor about their failing body. Rok, now trailed by her newly adopted "bribble," promises to keep working on solutions that help both Zero and the wider galaxy.

Back aboard ship, Jankom grumbles about cleaning tribble fluff out of every system while the others coo over Rok’s new pet. Chakotay updates their mission log: one step closer to a working proto-core, and one more reminder that scientific curiosity cuts both ways. Zero stares at the stars outside, wondering how much time their current form truly has left.

EthicalIssues: The dangers of genetic engineering intended to solve one problem but creating another.
Responsibilities scientists bear for unintended consequences of their work.
Zero’s struggle with bodily autonomy as their physical form begins to fail.
ContinuityNotes: Revisits tribbles with a twist, connecting Prodigy to one of Star Trek’s most famous species.
Introduces bosonite as a key component in building a new proto-core.
Foreshadows Zero’s later transformation and suit upgrades.
ThematicNotes: Owning mistakes without letting them define you forever.
Balancing scientific ambition with compassion for living subjects.
Found family extending even to odd little hybrid creatures.
BehindTheScenes: Offers a comedic yet heartfelt spin on tribbles for a new generation of viewers.
Gives Rok-Tahk another chance to shine as a scientist and caretaker.
Deepens the ongoing storyline about Zero’s fragile corporeal existence.

Title: Cracked Mirror
Antagonists: A shattered multiverse of alternate Voyagers and timelines
The risk of the Loom exploiting new tears in reality

StorySections.Text: The newly rebuilt proto-core carries the Protostar to Voyager’s last reported position—but instead of a smooth arrival, the jump rips open weakened spacetime. Both ships are scattered across a patchwork of alternate realities where familiar faces have very different histories.

Rok and Zero find themselves aboard a Voyager commanded by Tuvix, a composite of Tuvok and Neelix who never chose between his halves. Elsewhere, Dal, Gwyn, Jankom and Murf land on a Voyager from a universe where the Federation fell to the living construct. Each reality shows them a different version of what might have been if key choices had gone another way.

An attempt to regroup flings most of the team—and Chakotay—into the Mirror Universe, where they confront ruthless versions of Janeway and her crew. Maj'el is accidentally left behind in the prime reality and must work with Hologram Janeway and the Doctor to track the others through fluctuating quantum signatures. In the Mirror Universe, the cadets must convince an adversarial Janeway that the Loom threatens both their realities.

Realizing the rift will eventually tear all their Voyagers apart, Mirror Janeway reluctantly agrees to help. Using her ship’s agonizer-enhanced deflectors, she and the kids generate a multiversal pulse that knits the fractured timelines back together. The Protostar and the "true" Voyager finally re-align—though not before everyone has seen unsettling glimpses of lives they might have led.

On the restored prime Voyager, Chakotay and Janeway are reunited at last, sharing a brief but emotional reunion on the bridge. The cadets, shaken by how fragile reality has become, vow to tread more carefully with the proto-core. Zero quietly notes that if one bad jump can splinter the universe, they must make every remaining jump count.

EthicalIssues: Interfering with alternate realities, even in the name of saving one’s own.
Whether it is right to close a rift that might erase other versions of people who clearly exist and feel.
Using the brutal tools of the Mirror Universe for ostensibly noble ends.
ContinuityNotes: Features the return of the Mirror Universe and a new take on Tuvix that references Voyager’s controversial episode.
Shows the growing strain on the fabric of reality from repeated proto-core and temporal jumps.
Reunites Chakotay and Janeway, a major promise from early in the series.
ThematicNotes: Confronting the roads not taken—and the ones you are glad you avoided.
Seeing yourself in darker mirrors and choosing who you want to be.
The idea that every reality matters, even when you can only live in one.
BehindTheScenes: Celebrates Star Trek’s long history with mirror universes and alternate timelines.
Gives fans a playful but thoughtful look at different outcomes for Voyager’s crew.
Serves as a turning point where the scale of the Loom’s threat becomes undeniable.

Title: Ascension, Part I
Antagonists: Asencia’s renewed crusade against Federation and Solum alike
Admiral Jellico’s cautious orders that threaten to shut the mission down
A looming temporal war centered on Solum

StorySections.Text: Back aboard Voyager, the crew finally has a moment to breathe—until The Doctor confirms that Zero’s corporeal body is failing beyond repair. At the same time, Admiral Jellico orders both ships to return to Earth so Starfleet can seize control of the temporal crisis.

The Doctor proposes upgrading Zero’s next containment suit with sensory inputs so they can still feel the world, even without a traditional body. Zero asks Jankom to help, giving the Tellarite a rare chance to apply his engineering genius to a friend instead of a warp core. Their quiet project unfolds against a backdrop of tension as Janeway fumes over being pulled off the front lines.

Ilthuran secretly contacts Gwyn with terrible news: Asencia has seized control of Solum using advanced temporal weaponry, and the Rev-1 is en route to destroy Voyager and the Protostar. Janeway and Chakotay debate whether they can afford to defy Jellico’s orders when the fate of two civilizations hangs in the balance. In the end, they choose to stand their ground, scrambling both ships for battle.

Dal joins Nova Squadron in the skies while the rest of the cadets hurry back to the Protostar to help Chakotay. The Rev-1’s weapons tear through their defenses, leaving Voyager dangerously exposed and the Protostar badly damaged. As Asencia closes in, it becomes clear that this fight will decide who controls the future of both the Federation and Solum.

On the bridge, Janeway stares at a tactical display that grows more dire by the second as the Rev-1 moves into killing range. Zero, still in their failing body, quietly asks The Doctor to make sure their sacrifice means something if the worst happens. The episode ends with Voyager’s shields collapsing under a barrage of temporal fire.

EthicalIssues: Defying direct orders from Starfleet Command when lives and timelines are at stake.
Sending cadets into a battle involving weapons that can erase people from history.
Zero’s acceptance of their failing body and their right to choose how they face the end.
ContinuityNotes: Brings Asencia back to center stage as the primary antagonist, now wielding new temporal technology.
Shows Admiral Jellico again as a foil to Janeway’s more daring style of command.
Sets up the climactic Solum storyline that will carry through the rest of the season.
ThematicNotes: Coming to terms with mortality in a universe that keeps rewriting time.
When following orders conflicts with doing what’s right.
How upgrades and change can be acts of love, not just necessity.
BehindTheScenes: Begins the multi-part finale arc that will close out both the temporal storyline and the Solum conflict.
Gives Zero and Jankom a poignant shared subplot amid a large-scale battle.
Puts Janeway back in familiar territory: challenging Starfleet when she believes the stakes justify it.

Title: Ascension, Part II
Antagonists: The Rev-1 armed with the temporal "Incursor" weapon
Asencia’s campaign to prove Starfleet cannot protect the quadrant

StorySections.Text: The Rev-1 cripples the Protostar and strikes Voyager with the Incursor, a temporal weapon that accelerates the ship’s aging toward dust. Hull plates corrode before the crew’s eyes as entire decks threaten to crumble into nothing.

Zero realizes that the Incursor can be redirected—if someone is willing to stand at the heart of its temporal blast. Knowing their body is failing anyway, they volunteer for a desperate maneuver, asking Jankom and The Doctor to trust their calculations. Dal and Nova Squadron, meanwhile, struggle to hold off the Rev-1 long enough for any plan to matter.

Zero steps into the path of the weapon and uses their unique perception of time to twist the Incursor’s target from Voyager to Maj'el’s fighter, turning her ship into a lure. Maj'el leads the Rev-1 on a chase straight toward a volatile nebula nicknamed the "Boothby Supernova." The maneuver shreds Zero’s corporeal form, but the crew refuses to accept that as the end of their story.

The pursuing Rev-1 is caught in the supernova’s blast, and the redirected Incursor causes its own temporal weapons to rip the ship apart. In the quiet after the battle, Zero reveals a new containment suit Jankom built using The Doctor’s design—their consciousness saved in time. Starfleet orders both Voyager and the Protostar to head for Solum, making the coming confrontation official business.

In a hidden chamber, Asencia is revealed to have Wesley Crusher chained to a temporal harness, his Traveler abilities exploited to design the very weapons that nearly destroyed the fleet. She calmly observes that Starfleet’s stretched defenses have proven her point—and that the real war is just beginning.

EthicalIssues: Accepting one person’s self-sacrifice as the linchpin of a battle plan.
Weaponizing stolen knowledge from a captured Traveler.
Using temporal weapons that can undo lives rather than simply end them.
ContinuityNotes: Concludes the "Ascension" arc and transitions from defensive battles to an offensive mission toward Solum.
Gives Zero their upgraded containment suit that will define their look going forward.
Reveals how Asencia acquired her advanced temporal arsenal—by exploiting Wesley Crusher.
ThematicNotes: Sacrifice as a bridge between who you were and who you become.
Surviving a brush with non-existence and coming back changed but still yourself.
The danger of using extraordinary gifts—like Traveler powers—for conquest instead of exploration.
BehindTheScenes: Delivers one of the season’s most intense ship-to-ship battles and emotional character beats.
Provides a major showcase for Zero’s heroism and Jankom’s craftsmanship.
Further ties Prodigy into wider Trek lore through the fate of Wesley and the introduction of temporal super-weapons.

Title: Brink
Antagonists: Asencia’s regime on Solum backed by temporal weaponry
The escalating risk of open war between the Federation and the Vau N'Akat

StorySections.Text: With tensions between the Federation and the Vau N'Akat ready to explode, Solum becomes the flashpoint for a possible interstellar war. Janeway cannot send Starfleet officers behind enemy lines without inflaming the situation—so Gwyn proposes using the Protostar crew instead.

Because the cadets are not commissioned Starfleet personnel, Janeway authorizes them to infiltrate Solum as deniable assets. Maj'el resigns from Nova Squadron to join them, following her instincts rather than her orders. Their mission: rescue Gwyn’s father and uncover how Asencia is powering her impossible new weapons.

On Solum, the team encounters a younger version of Asencia who has joined the rebellion against her future self. She reveals that Wesley Crusher is the source of Asencia’s technology, his Traveler knowledge twisted into blueprints for paradox-inducing arms. Gwyn splits the team, sending some to liberate her father while others hunt for Wesley.

Wesley, once found, drops a bombshell: in the timeline he remembers, Ilthuran never should have been rescued and was meant to return to foment the very rebellion now unfolding. He allowed himself to be captured specifically so Asencia would build the devices they now need to untangle the paradox around Tars Lamora. Realizing they have already changed history, the crew improvises a new plan that centers on getting Wesley and Ilthuran safely off-world.

Dal uses a risky transporter maneuver to beam Wesley and Ilthuran directly back to Voyager, snatching them from Asencia’s grasp. On the bridge, Wesley warns Janeway that even Travelers cannot see past the branching futures now in play. The episode ends on the unsettling note that everyone—Travelers included—is flying blind.

EthicalIssues: Sending non-Starfleet adolescents into a war zone as "plausibly deniable" agents.
Accepting that a "correct" timeline involved leaving an ally to suffer to trigger a rebellion.
Wesley’s choice to be captured and exploited for the sake of a larger temporal strategy.
ContinuityNotes: Deepens the history of Solum and the Vau N'Akat civil conflict.
Clarifies Wesley’s long-game involvement in the season’s events.
Shows younger Asencia at odds with the tyrant she will one day become.
ThematicNotes: Standing on the brink of war and choosing whether to step back or leap forward.
The uneasy truth that some rebellions are born from terrible sacrifices.
How even those who see time differently can be surprised by the future.
BehindTheScenes: Builds toward the season’s final confrontation on Solum.
Allows Gwyn to take a more active strategic role in shaping her world’s fate.
Uses Wesley as a bridge between the logic of Travelers and the messy realities on the ground.

Title: Touch of Grey
Antagonists: Asencia’s attempt to weaponize the Loom against her enemies
The chaos of a civil war erupting on Solum

StorySections.Text: A badly injured Wesley recuperates in Voyager’s sickbay, his Traveler abilities offline after prolonged abuse. He grapples with the unsettling prospect of being "just" a Starfleet officer again while the universe still needs saving.

Janeway reminds Wesley that before he became something more, he was already someone she trusted on the Enterprise. Inspired, Wesley joins Janeway, Chakotay, and The Doctor on a daring mission to rescue the Protostar crew, who have been captured on Solum and slated to be fed to a Loom that Asencia has trapped and twisted into a weapon.

Deep within Asencia’s stronghold, the kids are forced to confront the Loom’s horrifying presence as it hungrily probes the edges of their reality. Janeway’s strike team fights through temporal distortions and collapsing corridors to reach them, relying on Wesley’s knowledge even without his powers. A precisely timed assault frees both the cadets and the Loom itself, breaking Asencia’s control.

Ilthuran seizes the moment to rouse his people against Asencia’s rule, sparking open rebellion across Solum. Civil war erupts almost instantly, with temporal weapons lighting up the skies. Remembering what it felt like to be underestimated early in her career, Janeway decides she cannot sit this fight out simply because of the Prime Directive.

Back aboard Voyager, Janeway tells her crew that sometimes the "grey" areas of Starfleet law are exactly where their duty lies. She commits to helping save Solum even if it means bending the rules, echoing the choices of her own mentors. Wesley looks out at the embattled world below, accepting that heroism does not depend on cosmic powers.

EthicalIssues: Intervening in a civil war despite the Prime Directive’s prohibitions.
The morality of trying to weaponize a sentient, extra-dimensional being like the Loom.
What Starfleet owes to worlds whose futures it has already altered.
ContinuityNotes: Escalates the Solum storyline into full-scale civil war.
Shows Janeway explicitly choosing intervention in a way that echoes past captains’ toughest decisions.
Further rehabilitates Wesley’s role as a Starfleet problem solver independent of his Traveler status.
ThematicNotes: Accepting that experience and age bring their own strengths to the table.
The "grey" spaces where rules and morality do not perfectly align.
Liberating others while ensuring you do not become what you are fighting.
BehindTheScenes: Pairs classic Trek questions about the Prime Directive with a very modern, serialized conflict.
Gives Janeway, Chakotay, The Doctor, and Wesley a rare team-up on a rescue mission.
Continues to develop the Loom from a simple threat into a complex presence in the story.

Title: Ouroboros, Part I
GuestCharacters: Starfleet crews aboard Voyager and Protostar
Antagonists: Asencia’s fleet of temporally armed warships
The Loom, drawn to the growing web of rifts

StorySections.Text: With her hold on Solum slipping, Asencia gambles everything on a final gambit: a fleet of ships equipped with temporal weapons aimed at major Federation targets across known space. Voyager and the Protostar form a thin defensive line between the armada and the rest of the galaxy.

Janeway and Chakotay lead the Starfleet elements in space, buying time with daring maneuvers and carefully chosen targets. Meanwhile, Wesley, Rok-Tahk, Zero, and Maj'el hunker down in a makeshift lab, racing to calculate a stable wormhole back to Tars Lamora—the key to resolving the original paradox. Their work is complicated by the constant tremors of temporal shockwaves rippling through the system.

Dal, Gwyn, Jankom, Murf, and Ilthuran beam to Solum to infiltrate Asencia’s stronghold and seize the source of her temporal tech. Gwyn confronts her older counterpart amid the chaos of the civil war, each accusing the other of betraying their people in different ways. As the fight spills into the streets, ordinary Vau N'Akat begin to choose sides.

In a climactic duel, Gwyn manages to defeat Asencia with the unexpected help of Vau N'Akat citizens who lend their support, physically and symbolically. Murf destroys Asencia’s Drednok, depriving her of her most fearsome enforcer. Using stolen technology, Dal and Jankom tear open the wormhole to Tars Lamora, collapsing the open rifts onto Asencia’s fleet and saving the Federation—at least for the moment.

As the fleet vanishes, a new threat emerges: the Loom pour out of the wormhole in vast numbers, drawn by the collapsing timelines like predators to wounded prey. Their presence threatens not just Solum or the Federation, but reality itself. Janeway realizes that closing the loop will require the Protostar to face its origin one last time.

EthicalIssues: Using temporal collapses as a weapon, even against an enemy bent on mass destruction.
Encouraging a population to overthrow its rulers when Starfleet partly caused the crisis.
Gwyn’s willingness to fight—and potentially kill—another version of herself for the greater good.
ContinuityNotes: Begins the two-part series finale that ties together the Loom, Tars Lamora, and Solum storylines.
Explains how the wormhole back to Tars Lamora is finally opened in a controlled way.
Marks the apparent defeat of Asencia’s fleet even as a bigger danger appears.
ThematicNotes: The ouroboros image of a snake eating its tail, as actions circle back to their beginnings.
Revolutions powered not just by weapons, but by ordinary people taking a stand.
The idea that stopping one apocalypse can inadvertently invite another.
BehindTheScenes: Kicks off a finale that must resolve both a temporal paradox and a planetary civil war.
Gives Gwyn her long-awaited confrontation with Asencia.
Shows Murf once again playing a crucial, unexpectedly destructive role in saving the day.

Title: Ouroboros, Part II
Antagonists: The Loom swarm threatening to consume reality
The lingering scars of the Mars attack on First Contact Day

StorySections.Text: With the Loom flooding through the wormhole, Voyager and the Protostar have one last chance to tie off the paradox at its origin point: Tars Lamora. Janeway orders a daring plan—send the Protostar into the heart of the storm, guarded by Voyager to the last.

The Doctor backs up Hologram Janeway’s program so Chakotay can carry her forward if the worst happens. The Protostar plunges into the wormhole, fighting through temporal turbulence until it lands once again on Tars Lamora at the critical moment that began the entire saga. By replaying events with new understanding, the crew manages to close the loop in a way that sends the Loom back to their own dimension.

In the aftermath, Janeway leads an official first contact mission with the Vau N'Akat, finally meeting them not as enemies or future tyrants but as partners. Wesley tells Dal that the universe still has plans that require the crew to stay together, hinting at adventures beyond even Traveler sight. He visits his mother Beverly and brother Jack, grounding his cosmic journey in family once more.

Time jumps forward: the kids enroll at Starfleet Academy, trading stolen starships for crowded lecture halls. On First Contact Day, however, the Mars attack shakes the Federation to its core, echoing events seen in Star Trek: Picard. Janeway is pulled out of retirement and tasked with turning a new Protostar-class USS Prodigy into a training ship for the group, complete with field promotions to ensign.

Dal relinquishes the captain’s chair to Gwyn, choosing to serve as her first officer as they step onto the bridge of the USS Prodigy for the first time. Hologram Janeway, now upgraded as an Emergency Command Hologram, welcomes them aboard with a familiar twinkle. The series closes on the image of the young officers at their stations, ready to face "wondrous and terrible" things yet to come.

EthicalIssues: Launching a starship into a temporal singularity with a crew of recent cadets to save all of reality.
Balancing the need to correct a paradox against the lives and histories already shaped by it.
Starfleet’s decision to put traumatised young heroes back in the line of fire after the Mars attack.
ContinuityNotes: Closes the loop on the Tars Lamora paradox introduced in Season 1.
Directly ties Prodigy into the events surrounding the Mars synth attack referenced in Star Trek: Picard.
Establishes the USS Prodigy and the cadets’ new status as ensigns, setting the stage for potential future stories.
ThematicNotes: Endings that are also beginnings, symbolized by the ouroboros imagery.
The idea that chosen family can become the core of a new Starfleet crew.
Accepting that the future will hold both wonder and pain, and choosing to face it anyway.
BehindTheScenes: Serves as the capstone for Prodigy’s two-season arc while leaving the door open for new adventures.
Weaves together threads from across the modern Star Trek timeline, including connections to Picard.
Gives each member of the Protostar crew a clear starting point for the next chapter of their lives in Starfleet.
